title: The Dow Fell 29 Points Because the China Trade Truce Lacks Details
text:
Text size

What Deal? The main U.S. stock indexes closed slightly below breakeven as optimism surrounding a partial trade deal between the U.S. and China continued to wane. Boeing (ticker: BA) got a new chairman. WeWork is seeking for new cash after the planned IPO was pushed off. In today’s After the Bell, we...

Not Good Enough

Stocks were largely flat on Monday, as the market’s reaction to a partial trade deal—touted by President Donald Trump last Friday—stayed lukewarm. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen 29.23 points, or 0.11%, to close at 26787.36. The S&P 500 lost 4.12 points, or 0.14%, to finish at 2966.15, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 8.39 points, or 0.10%, to close at 8048.65.

Despite an upbeat meeting with China’s top trade negotiator and the announcement of a “phase one” trade agreement, investors still have many questions unanswered, and many concerns unresolved.

The new agreement reportedly involved China’s commitments on its currency, financial services, intellectual property practices, as well as purchases of American farm products. In return, the U.S. won’t increase the tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese imports from 25% to 30% this week.

Still, the details of the deal haven’t been hammered out yet, the key structural issues remained off the table, existing tariffs on billions worth of goods are still in effect, and China doesn’t have a good record of following its promises. After all, Chinese media didn’t refer to last week’s negotiation as a “deal” to “avoid fueling expectations too fast, too soon,” wrote Ipek Ozkardeskaya of London Capital Group in a Monday note.

Editor's Choice

“The progress in US-China trade negotiations should improve the investor sentiment across the board. But given how fast the wind can change direction, investors will likely prevent from crying victory too soon,” wrote Ozkardeskaya.

But one thing is clear: The U.S.-China trade tensions have continued to take a toll on Chinese trade data. Chinese exports fell 3.2% in September from the same period last year, coming well below the consensus of a 2.8% decline and the 1.0% drop in August. This marks a contraction for the fifth straight month. Shipments to the U. S.—the main driver of the decline—fell 21.9% in September. Total imports fell an even sharper 8.5%, as compared to the 5.6% decline in the prior month and economists’ consensus for a 6.0% drop. “If Beijing wants to blow off some steam, it should do its best to sign a partial and even a comprehensive trade deal with the U.S.,” wrote Ozkardeskaya.

Despite the many uncertainties around the “mini deal,” investors may shift their focus to Corporate America for some time, as U.S. companies kick off the third-quarter earnings season this week.

Major banks will announce their results in the coming days, including JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Goldman Sachs Group (GS), Citigroup (C), and Wells Fargo (WFC) on Tuesday, Bank of America (BAC) on Wednesday, and Morgan Stanley (MS) on Thursday. As the Federal Reserve is expected to cut rates for a third time by the end of October, banks’ income will likely stay under pressure. Investors will focus on their ability to manage operating costs and stay disciplined in a low-rate environment.

Investors will also watch earnings from Netflix (NFLX), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), International Business Machines (IBM), Philip Morris International (PM), and Coca-Cola (KO) this week.
